title: Court says Mass. father’s battle over LGBTQ-friendly lessons excludes books on gender stereotypes
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Federal judge rules that two books on gender stereotypes fall outside a lawsuit challenging LGBTQ-friendly lessons in Lexington schools.
The lawsuit, filed by a father named Alan L., focuses on issues of marriage, gender, and sexuality in school materials.
Judge specified only materials depicting LGBTQ+ content require opt-out, excluding 'Pink Is For Boys' and 'Except When They Don’t'.

title: Roman Anthony set to join Team USA for World Baseball Classic if he passes physical
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Roman Anthony joins Team USA for World Baseball Classic, replacing Corbin Carroll pending a physical.
At 21, Anthony will be Team USA's youngest player and aims to contribute as part of a strong outfield.
Garrett Whitlock joins Anthony as the only Red Sox players representing Team USA at the World Baseball Classic.

title: $20M penthouse at Taylor Swift’s rumored wedding venue hits market
author: Regina Cole
bullets: A $20M penthouse at Ocean House in Westerly, RI is now on the market.
Penthouse features 4,696 sq. ft. with three bedrooms, four bathrooms, and ocean views.
Owners gain access to Ocean House amenities, including a private beach and members-only club.

title: 10 Celtics stats that should show encouragement and discouragement entering All-Star break
author: Conor Roche
bullets: The Celtics are second in the Eastern Conference with a 35-19 record entering the All-Star break.
Jaylen Brown averages 29.3 points per game, earning his first All-Star starter nod.
Celtics are 12-14 in clutch games, ranked 21st, worst among teams with playoff spots.

title: Your Cape Cod winter guide: 20 things to do during the cold months
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Cape Cod offers a diverse range of winter activities across its 15 towns, from museums to outdoor trails.
Visitors can explore attractions like the Sandwich Glass Museum, Cape Cod Rail Trail, and Truro Vineyards.
Dining and entertainment options include Bamboo Chinese Cuisine, Devil's Purse Brewing, and Cape Cod Theatre Company.

title: She’s running Boston for people like her with Type 1 Diabetes
author: Kelly Chan
bullets: Kristine Lapczynski, a pharmacist from North Carolina, will run the 2026 Boston Marathon for Breakthrough T1D advocacy.
Diagnosed with Type 1 Diabetes for 23 years, Lapczynski manages blood sugar and insulin while training for the marathon.
She previously lived in Boston, attended MCPHS University, and volunteers annually at the Boston Marathon.

title: She picked up running at age 45. Now at 61, she’s on track for her Six Star medal.
author: Kelly Chan
bullets: Andrea Nwamarah, 61, is running the Boston Marathon to support the MEB Foundation, which promotes healthy youth lifestyles.
Nwamarah, a registered nurse, began her running journey at age 45 with a 'Walk to Run' class at the YMCA.
She aims to receive her Six Star medal by completing the world's major marathons, with Boston being her latest achievement.

title: Boston Marathon runner inspired by aunt’s blindness raises money for the visually impaired
author: Kelly Chan
bullets: Paige Stopperich, 29, from Somerville, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon for the Massachusetts Association for the Blind and Visually Impaired.
Inspired by her aunt Shannon's blindness, Stopperich aims to support MABVI's work aiding people with vision loss.
MABVI provides rehabilitation, assistive technology, mobility training, and peer groups to help the visually impaired stay independent.

title: Drake Maye says he doesn’t regret marrying young. What readers said.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Drake Maye, Patriots QB, married Anne Michael Maye at 22 and supports early marriage, citing personal contentment.
Readers shared varied experiences: some celebrated long marriages, others viewed young marriage as a regrettable choice.
Feedback reflected different opinions on early marriage's benefits and challenges, highlighting lack of a universal blueprint.

title: Driver accused of killing art collector in Back Bay hit-and-run deemed mentally incompetent
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: William Haney, 42, was deemed mentally incompetent in a hit-and-run case involving art collector John Axelrod.
Haney, diagnosed with schizophrenia, pleaded not guilty to murder and animal cruelty charges related to a Jan. 3 collision.
Judge ordered further examination at Bridgewater State Hospital to evaluate Haney's competency for future trial proceedings.
